results.title: The Company of strangers [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Scott, David Wilson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A bus breaks down in the wilderness. Eight elderly women, average age 71, are stranded at a deserted farmhouse. They have only their wits, their memories, and eventually some roasted frogs’ legs, to sustain them. Through the long days and nights this remarkable group of strangers share their life stories and exchange intimate thoughts; turning the crisis into a magical time of humour and spirit. Featuring non-professional actors and spontaneous dialogue, this memorable film dissolves the barrier between fiction and reality, weaving a heartwarming tale of friendship and courage. Cast: Cissy Meddings, Mary Meigs, Catherine Roche, Michelle Sweeney, Beth Webber, Alice Diabo, Constance Garneau, Winifred Holden. Script, Gloria Demers, Cynthia Scott, David Wilson and Sally Bochner. Cinematography, David de Volpi. Music, Marie Bernard. Editing, David Wilson.

results.title: The Communal sense of modesty = Il commune senso del pudore
results.creator_credit: Alberto Sordi, Fausto Saraceni and Rizzoli Film
results.brief_description: Four humorous vignettes starring and directed by top Italian comic actor Alberto Sordi which take place on the same day. The first tells of a conservative married couple in search of a movie theatre which take place on the same day. The second is about life in a successful magazine company. The third deals with the increasing popularity of sex magazines in Italy. The fourth and final story tells of a ‘primadonna’ actress constantly throwing tantrums in a film studio. In Italian language with no English subtitles.

results.title: The Comic Spirit (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A look at the different elements of comedy, performed and workshopped by the New Shakespeare Company from the Open Air Theatre in Regent’s Park. Shows sequences from modern comedy routines and relates these ideas of the comic genre to scenes from a number of Shakespearian comedies.

results.title: Realms of light: the baroque
results.creator_credit: Eugene Marner, Carole Lucia Satrina and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from the commissions arising from the church’s campaign against the Reformation to works commissioned by the Royal and wealthy of Europe in the 17th century. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on dramatic depictions of religious scenes in the work of Caravaggio and Bernini as well as the work of such artists as Velazquez and Rembrandt. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Play of light
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The Republic of Venice had enjoyed great power and prosperity for many centuries before the Renaissance, and the city in its unique setting has long been one of the jewels of Italy. By the 16th Century, however, its political power was passing its peak. The artistic achievements express confidence and an enthusiasm for experimentation. Artists such as Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese highlight the flavour of the Venetian Renaissance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Early Renaissance of Italy
results.creator_credit: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Covers the revival and reinterpretation of the classical tradition in the works of Florentine artists Masaccio, Donatello, and Ghiberti. Discusses how these artists exemplify the merging of Christian and humanistic values. Examines the realism of Jan van Eyck and the spiritual crisis of Northern Europe as revealed in Gruenwald’s Isenheim altarpiece. Discusses the spirit of the Renaissance as reflected in Durer’s work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Distanced creations
results.creator_credit: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Neo-Impressionists and Post-Impressionists abandoned the techniques of the Impressionists, however the diversity of styles and techniques greatly varied among the celebrated artists of the time. Colour, form and content was influenced by an awareness of non-European art such as Japanese woodcuts, and scientific theories of colour which artists Seurat and Cezanne practised with almost mathematical precision. Gaugin’s lifelong passion for the exotique, Van Gogh’s highly emotive style or Lautrec’s interest in the bohemian side of Paris represent the creative energies of the period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: A White garment of churches
results.creator_credit: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Examines Romanesque and Gothic churches as evidence of the values of the society that created them. Shows the effect of monasticism and pilgrimage on Romanesque church architecture. Gothic architecture and sculpture, exemplified in the churches of Chatres and St Denis, are discussed as evidence of a new theology and profound changes in medieval society. As most people, including Kings and Queens could not write, the visual images of Christian art were called “Books of the illiterate”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: A Fresh view: impressionism and post impressionism
results.creator_credit: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from the impressionists to the Post-Impressionists. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the works of such artists as Gustave Courbet, Georges Seurat, Vincent Van Gogh and Paul Cezanne, presenting the rejection of academic techniques that impressionism represented and its celebration of colour and light to the progression of these themes in the works of Post-Impressionism. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.
results.title_for_label: A Fresh view: impressionism and post impressionism
